title: Chaining Sentences with `.i`
goal: Connect multiple bridi into flowing Lojban discourse using `.i`.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

Vocabulary speed round — translate to English as fast as you can:

1. mi cu sipna     → ?
2. ti cu melbi     → ?
3. do cu xamgu     → ?
4. mi cu ciska     → ?
5. do cu tcidu ti  → ?
6. mi cu prami do  → ?

(Answers: I sleep. This is beautiful. You are good. I write. You read this. I love you.)

Now say each Lojban sentence aloud, with clear stress on the penultimate syllable.

New Material (5-7 min)

The Sentence Separator .i

mi tavla .i do citka — I talk. You eat.

In English, we use periods and capital letters to separate sentences. In Lojban, we use .i (pronounced as a pause followed by "ee").

How .i Works

The .i goes between sentences, not at the end:

Lojban English
mi cadzu I walk.
mi cadzu .i do sipna I walk. You sleep.
mi cadzu .i do sipna .i ti melbi I walk. You sleep. This is beautiful.

Each .i marks the boundary between one bridi and the next.

Pronunciation

The period (.) in Lojban represents a glottal stop — a tiny pause, like the break in "uh-oh." When you say .i:

  1. Make a small pause (the .)
  2. Say "ee" (the i)

Practice: mi tavla .i do citka

  • Say "mi tavla"
  • Pause briefly
  • Say "ee"
  • Say "do citka"

Why Not Just Pause?

In speech, pauses can be ambiguous. The .i makes sentence boundaries explicit, even in rapid speech or written text. It's not optional — it's the standard way to chain sentences.

Examples

Lojban Gloss English
mi citka .i do pinxe I eat [.i] you drink I eat. You drink.
ti xamgu .i ta xlali this good [.i] that bad This is good. That is bad.
mi prami do .i do prami mi I love you [.i] you love me I love you. You love me.
do cadzu .i mi sipna you walk [.i] I sleep You walk. I sleep.

Notice the third example: the same pronouns, same verb, but switched positions tell a different story. And .i cleanly separates the two claims.

A New Pronoun: ta

You've learned ti (this, near speaker). Now meet ta:

Pronoun Meaning Distance
ti this near speaker
ta that near listener
tu that (yonder) far from both

These form a trio. Today, focus on ti and ta.

Key Point

.i separates sentences in Lojban. Pronounce it as a pause + "ee". Use it between every bridi when chaining multiple statements.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Chain the Sentences

Combine each pair into one Lojban utterance using .i:

  1. I eat. + You drink.
  2. This is good. + That is bad.
  3. I sleep. + You walk.
  4. You talk to me. + I love you.
Answers
  1. mi citka .i do pinxe
  2. ti xamgu .i ta xlali
  3. mi sipna .i do cadzu
  4. do tavla mi .i mi prami do

Exercise 2: Translation (Lojban → English)

Translate to English:

  1. mi ciska .i do tcidu
  2. ti melbi .i ta xlali
  3. do sipna .i mi cadzu
  4. mi klama .i do klama
Answers
  1. I write. You read.
  2. This is beautiful. That is bad.
  3. You sleep. I walk.
  4. I go. You go.

Exercise 3: Build a Three-Sentence Chain

Create a chain of three bridi using .i. Use at least three different gismu.

Example: mi sipna .i do citka .i ti xamgu (I sleep. You eat. This is good.)

Try making your own, then say it aloud.

Sample answers
  • mi cadzu .i do tavla .i ti melbi
  • do pinxe .i mi ciska .i ta xlali
  • mi prami do .i do prami mi .i ti xamgu

items.text: This is good. + That is bad.
You talk to me. + I love you.

items.answer: This is beautiful. That is bad.

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud in Lojban:

  1. "I walk. You sleep."
  2. "This is beautiful. That is bad."
  3. "I love you. You love me."
  4. "I read. You write. This is good."

Answer key:

  1. mi cadzu .i do sipna
  2. ti melbi .i ta xlali
  3. mi prami do .i do prami mi
  4. mi tcidu .i do ciska .i ti xamgu

prompts.text: "I read. You write. This is good."

sections.content:
Summary

You learned that .i separates sentences in Lojban, pronounced as a glottal pause followed by "ee." You practiced chaining two and three bridi together, and met the pronoun ta (that, near listener). You also learned xlali (bad), completing all 12 gismu for Week 1.

Tomorrow preview: Vocabulary drill day — you'll review all 12 gismu and test yourself on everything from the week.
